reviewSummary.text: One of the nicer parks in AZ. Has nice big spots, plenty of privacy if you like to cut loose a little. It’s close to food and shopping. Beautiful trails to hike. Plenty of open space for your pets. Biking or walking your choice. Bathrooms are nice and clean. And wildlife walking through your campsite. Shame they had to raise the rate to 50 a night , not really worth it with no on site sewer or pool or anything to do like the parks that charge the higher price.

little-rock-ar-maumelle-park-campground.editorialSummary: This waterfront public campground features areas for hiking & nature viewing, plus boat access.

reviewSummary.text:
This is a great campground and a great location very close to Little Rock Arkansas. There are at least five sections in the campground. Our first two nights we stayed in B at site 24 which was nice and on the water. Our last night we stayed in section a at site 15 which was also nice. We preferred area B if you’re going to be on the water, but if you’re OK overlooking water then the area D and C were much more wooded. You pretty much can’t go wrong in any area. Even if you camp on the water, don’t think that you can just walk down to the edge because there’s a lot of rocks and brush It’s a river not a lake so it’s not like you can just step into the water. We stayed in mid October and there were a lot of RVs here, but everyone was spaced out very well so you still had plenty of privacy. We didn’t see walking trails, but the roads are easy to walk on throughout the campground. It’s a good place for fishing and there are picnic areas, but we saw very few young families here.
We had water and 30 A in the B area, then water and 50 A in the A area. There were at least two dump sites within the COE property.

coronado-ca-silver-strand-state-beach.editorialSummary: Sandy space with ocean & bay shorelines offering fishing, swimming & picnicking, plus RV camping.

reviewSummary.text:
We had an awesome time camping in our RV.
We were warmly greeted by Melissa (staff), who was super nice and she got us checked in and  she gave us a campground map and rules.
Anthony(staff),  was very helpful & friendly. He helped us find our RV spot. Anthony was walking by our campsite and noticed I was having trouble getting  my RV plugged up and he showed me how to do it properly.
The campground was very organized and well run and all the staff were efficient & pleasant.
The overall campground had a great atmosphere and in the later evening it was nice & quiet.
The other campers were friendly. The kids were well behaved and dogs too.
We had fun talking and interacting with the other campers and we petted quite a few dogs.
We met a lot of nice people.
It was a great place to relax. We didn't think about anything except taking it easy.
Tip: use the Mobile dump service guy to make it easy.

Nature’s beauty at its best!

We went on Memorial Day and it was not at all crowded. Parking fee 10$ .

When we reached weather was nice and sunny but by afternoon it was cloudy and rainy.  Always bring a jacket as weather can be very unpredictable here.

You can’t swim here as water is really deep.

We walked on the trail along the beach and there are enough restrooms along the trail (if you are pregnant this is really helpful lol ). The restrooms are not very clean but okay .

Overall a very peaceful and relaxing place, just bring your own food , games and mat .

perris-ca-lake-perris-recreation-area.editorialSummary: Reserve on a lake, popular for boating & hikes in rocky terrain home to bobcats & birdlife.

reviewSummary.text:
What a beautiful state recreation area of Lake Perris.

I came here for SSBD and camp out for the festival. Watching the sunrise here was so magical. It’s very easy to find a lot that you’re staying in. I didn’t know this place existed and it’s so cool. How much area it has. Especially coming here to swim in the lake. Will definitely come here again to camp with my friends.

frisco-co-heaton-bay-campground.editorialSummary: Basic lakefront & mountain campground with 81 sites open May to October close to hiking trails.

reviewSummary.text: We stayed a both campsites with and without hook ups. Both very nice, quiet, lots of trees and some sites with view. We hit the peak of color change in the fall.   Bike trails connect to the campground- again absolutely beautiful. Very nice trails. Camp hosts friendly and helpful.

lakewood-co-bear-creek-lake-park.editorialSummary: Massive 2,600-acre open area for camping, hiking & horseback riding, with a lake for swimming.

reviewSummary.text:
The park is a true treasure. A Grand tree canopy shades a clean well-kept trail that winds beside a peaceful creek. Walking here feels cool, even on bright days.

There are many picnic areas, even with sturdy tables and trimmed grass. Trails stretch wide for biking and horseback riding with clear signs to guide of return. For those who fish there are spots perfect for a relaxing afternoon

The grounds are clean, paths are safe, and the natural beauty is well preserved. A perfect place for families, hikers, and nature lovers alike.

loveland-co-boyd-lake-state-park.editorialSummary: Placid lakeside park featuring boating, fishing & other water sports plus a campground & more.

reviewSummary.text:
Tight fit, busy local recreation area.
Pros:  Beautiful walking and bike trails. Nice laundry and shower facilities.
Cons:  super tight pull through sites. Most will not accommodate a 32 foot rig and tow vehicle. Roads are very rough inside the park. No directional signs when entering so we had to circle around 3 times to find water and figure out how to get into our site.  “Waterfront” classification is deceptive. You can’t even see the water and are at least 200 yard walk to lake. Worst part is that the local swim beach and boat ramp are accessed through the same gate as campground. Weekend visitation to the beach was incredibly busy. When returning to our campsite on a Sunday afternoon,, we were stuck in an hour long traffic jam trying to get into the campground. Very poor design. Leaving a day early, just not happy here.

The lake and surroundings are chic. We drove by and we just needed to spend the night. Booked an online place. When we arrived, it turned out that regardless of whether we would walk or not, they got a fee of 10 dollars per entry. There is no light in the toilets, the water column did not work. I think 28 + 10 dollars for a place for a tent is a lot. But the lake is very beautiful at sunset.

Don't go during busy times. People are extremely inconsiderate and walk through your camp constantly day and night. It gets pretty loud as well when busy. The restrooms are nice, and they have showers. The water will dry out your hair and skin. If we didn't have people walking through our camp site every time we camped here, it would be more enjoyable.

lewes-de-cape-henlopen-state-park.editorialSummary: Peaceful preserve on former military base featuring beaches, disc golf, hikes & observation tower.

reviewSummary.text: This a wonderful park! I want to highlight especially the Bike Barn where you can loan adult and kid bikes and helmets for free (donations appreciated!) and the staff is kind, friendly and eager help. The loop is 3 miles which you can easily bike with just a few moderate/gentle hills. A short walk from the Bike Barn is a fantastic playground which is partially shaded, with benches and picnic tables in the shade as well- a gift for parents with young kids. We can’t wait to come back! Oh and they have a water station where you can refill your water bottles!

What a beautiful park! All of the campsites were very nice, including the primitive sites. Those are very wooded in wish we had more wooded sites up at the RV section. The bath house was immaculate and very hot water.

brooksville-fl-silver-lake-campground.editorialSummary: Relaxed lakeside campground offering a boat ramp & picnic shelter, along with a bathhouse.

reviewSummary.text: Nice campground,  most spots were not very long but level.  24 hr traffic noise from the highway but fishing was fun

debary-fl-lake-monroe-park.editorialSummary: Renovated park with boat ramps, camping, playground, trails, picnic areas, fishing docks & pavilion.

reviewSummary.text: Plenty of seating, right off the busy road. There is actual bathrooms and a clean Bay Area to drop a boat. Fee is only $2 to drop a boat on the launch.

Kate's Fish Camp RV Park has some amazing nature and the campsites are a breeze to park on. They have an awesome outdoor shower, plus the bathrooms are super clean and well-maintained. You'll have water and electric hookups, but keep in mind there's no sewer or dump station on site.  The campground is also right next to the bike trail, which is super convenient. You can have a lot of fun biking around Gainesville, Florida.
Overall, it was a super nice experience with reasonable prices. I'd definitely go back. The campground has a really cozy feel.

One last thing, Monica, one of the owners, makes amazing soaps you should try! You can usually find samples in the office.

florida-high-springs-fl-o-leno-state-par.editorialSummary: State park on the Santa Fe river featuring a historical suspension bridge, plus camping & hiking.

reviewSummary.text: Walked the river trail and discovered that two of the walkway bridges were closed. We had to walk down into the natural "trench" to continue on the trail.  Hopefully bridges will be repaired soon. Otherwise it's a great trail. Remember to bring bug spray and wear sturdy shoes.  There is a swimming area, but largely depends on how high the water level is.

jacksonville-fl-little-talbot-island-sta.editorialSummary: Barrier-island nature area with sandy beaches & activities such as kayaking, surfing & picnicking.

reviewSummary.text: It's an awesome place to fish and camp. Restrooms are available kids playground and the beach is further out from the jetty.  The only con is thd closing hours, I feel like they could extend it back to the way it was. Im pretty tired of the park closing when the fish starts biting.

keystone-heights-fl-mike-roess-gold-head.editorialSummary: 2,000 acres of wildlife-friendly springs, lakes & marshes for camping, hiking, swimming & canoeing.

reviewSummary.text: Great place for a fun day of exploring and getting the kids out of the house! Plenty of trails, wide open spaces, and a beautiful lake. The kids loved running around, spotting wildlife, and just being outdoors. Perfect spot for a family picnic and some fresh air away from screens. We’ll definitely be back! Special mention of Debbie, she was really helpful and kind.

melbourne-beach-fl-sebastian-inlet-state.editorialSummary: Park boasting salt-water fishing including mackerel, snook & bluefish plus surfing & scuba diving.

reviewSummary.text: My wife and I camped here for two nights on 17-19 August, 2025.  I booked the reservation online about a month prior to our visit using the Florida State Park's app. I had tried to camp here last winter, (snowbird season) and it was booked solid from December through March.  We arrived at the park about noon, but the Ranger at the office would not let us check in early.  She did however, allow us to drop our travel trailer in the parking lot beside the park office so we could drive down to nearby Vero Beach to do some exploring.  We got back to the park at about 5:00 pm, got checked in, and set up in our Campsite (#9), which was overlooking the water, but had zero shade trees around it (and it was very hot during our stay).  The site had water and electric hookups, but as with most Florida State Parks, you had to use a dump station near the campground exit to empty your holding tank.  The restroom/shower facility was only about a 75 yard walk away, and it was clean and had good hot water pressure and decent ventilation (but no air conditioning).  This is a very nice State Park and its very popular, particularly with surfers and saltwater fishermen. The beaches on both the north and south sides of the inlet are nice, but you have to be careful when there is any kind of storm brewing in the Atlantic because they rip currents can get very dangerous.  There is also a nice and calm swimming lagoon on the north side and to the west of US Hwy A1A where it's safe for kids to swim.  There are also lots of pavilions and picnic tables available.  There is a concession building on the north side of the inlet near the jetty, but it's still closed after getting ravaged by hurricanes over the past few years.  We did notice there were two food truck vendors parked in the area under the north off ramp of the bridge.   It does get very hot and buggy here during the summer months, but the winter months in this area are delightfully pleasant with low humidity and mostly clear skies.   If you are "Glamper" like my wife and I (i.e., we don't cook at the campsite, but rather dine out), then you will have to drive about 12 miles south to Vero Beach, or about 15 miles north to Melbourne Beach to find any restaurants.  Vero Beach has several very good restaurants that run the full gambit of shabby to sheik.  Melbourne Beach only has a small handful, but we at a place up there called Sand on the Beach that wasn't too bad.

micanopy-fl-paynes-prairie-preserve-stat.editorialSummary: State preserve with various wildlife habitats & trails for hiking, horseback riding & bicycling.

reviewSummary.text: Incredibly beautiful park. Wild horses, buffalo, alligators, so much wildlife. Well maintained trained, staff and rangers are the best. Visitor center is great to get maps and ask questions. Too much to put into a review, but go to the visitor center and grab a map. Boardwalks, lakes, observation towers.

ocala-fl-santos-trailhead-campground.editorialSummary: Campground & trailhead with restrooms, water, picnic pavilions & access to mountain-biking trails.

reviewSummary.text: Great little campground next to the trails at Santos in Ocala. 25 sites and 1 bathroom. Last star was for facilities as the men's room had 1 toilet. Campground roads are well paved and sites are decently level.  Close access to hiking, paved biking, walking and some of the best mountain bike trails in Florida made the campground a must stay. If the facilities were improved and cleaned more regularly I would move here happily.  Close stores for food and necessities as well as thrift stores and antiques.

orange-city-fl-blue-spring-state-park.editorialSummary: Park featuring a cool-water spring on the St. Johns River that's popular for swimming & kayaking.

reviewSummary.text: Very unique experience! We spontaneously decided to drive up here during our stay in Orlando. We enjoyed the boardwalk, got to see manatees and even one gator when we took the 1h boat tour. Our guide Lee was very funny and we learned a bunch about the area and St Johns River. Restrooms were clean and well maintained.

osprey-fl-oscar-scherer-state-park.editorialSummary: Acres of woods & water for camping, swimming, fishing, canoeing & hiking miles of trails.

reviewSummary.text: Nice State Park with hiking, walking and cycling trails, cheap admission fees. Plenty of native plants and fauna to watch and even a man-made lake to fish if you desire. Ample pavilion areas for family activity and get togethers. Very clean bathrooms as well.

pensacola-beach-fl-fort-pickens-campgrou.editorialSummary: An RV and tent-friendly park with 200 campsites offering water, electricity & grill areas,

reviewSummary.text: Great place to camp for a short stay.  Camped in Loop C with a 37' motorhome.  Site was clean and well maintained with 50amp electric and water hookup at the site. They are very particular about not parking your tow vehicle on the grass since it does damage that costs the National Park money. There is overflow parking available if needed but it's limited so try to book a site long enough to fit all your vehicles.  You cannot park your tow vehicle parallel on your site.  All vehicles must be parked pulled straight in on your pad.  You will receive a citation if parked the wrong way or touching the grass.  Cell service on Verizon and T-Mobile is very slow and sometimes doesn't work at all. Check the Blue Angels practice dates on their website and you'll be able to view them flying over Fort Pickens. Best viewing is from the actual fort along the seawall.

saint-petersburg-fl-fort-de-soto-park-ca.editorialSummary: 238-site, waterfront campground with RV hookups, showers, grills & picnic tables, plus a camp store.

reviewSummary.text: Best campground in South Florida, very peaceful atmosphere. No partying in this area. Everybody was very polite, staff and campers. We enjoyed nature and its tranquility. The campsites that are closest to the 200s are more busy and lots of RVs, the ones from 1 to 60 something have more tents and are more calm. The ones with the dogs have an abundance of dogs haha. Bathrooms are very clean. Biking trails are kept nicely, and biking to the ocean and historical marks are definitely a must. Watch out for the racoons, their homes are the trees surrounding the campsite, they will be there and will steal your marshmallows if you let haha

sebring-fl-highlands-hammock-state-park.editorialSummary: Huge park offers full camping facilities, trails & wildlife in an old-growth cypress swamp.

reviewSummary.text: Neat place to enjoy nature! Bug spray reccomended. The Cyprus trees are my favorite. Lots of trails. Saw some water snakes and wild dogs.

Thanks to an earlier than usual check-in. My wife and I were able to get in an excellent round-trip ride to Plummer before the rain came. The suggestion to have lunch at the Gateway diner was excellent. Mike greeted us when we arrived and made our one night visit here very easy.

Great place for breakfast. I wouldn't know about much else.
Staff is extremely attentive, and the food Wow!
Hopefully y'all enjoy as much as we did

grafton-il-pere-marquette-state-park.editorialSummary: Lodge & 8,000-acre nature area for water & winter sports, birding, hunting, riding & camping.

reviewSummary.text:
This park is a nature's lovers paradise. Located in Grafton Illinois at the confluence of the Mississippi and Illinois Rivers.

We took the main circle drive thru the park which had many pull offs for you to get out and enjoy the views. Unfortunately we never made it back to see the main Lodge.

A great park for camping and hiking. The visitors center open daily from 8-3pm. Plenty of parking as well as public facilities thru out.

6:30pm in mid September. The campground is quiet, just a little road noise, the grass is green and mowed, our site, #19 is clean and we’re watching the river from our site. I stopped in the restrooms/showers and they’re clean and fine. We have 30/50 amp electricity hook up, and water spigot at the end of our site (see photo). A water refill and dump station could be seen as we drive in as well as a dumpster for bagged trash. Everything is lovely, just wish we had more than an overnight here.
We paid only $13 due to having a Senior Lifetime pass, otherwise it would’ve been $26.

I did a bike packing trip from Chicago. I loved it so much that I stayed a 2nd night!This place is a gem!  The setting is beautiful; this campground is extremely well-maintained.  The shower rooms and bathrooms are very clean. The staff is friendly and helpful. The manger, Elaine, was most gracious, accommodating  and kind.
You get a bucket of firewood at no charge!  You do hear a little traffic but it's not bad. Some people have commented that you could do better in Wisconsin or Michigan, but that's like comparing apples to bananas.  Deer Grove Preserve is in Palatine, but I don't feel that being located in a suburb detracts from the beauty. I did visit on a weekday (post Labor Day), so I imagine that you'd hear more activity when visiting on a weekend -- I was the only tent-camper on site!
This is a perfect place for a Microadventure!

First time ever camping and my experience was amazing. This location is great, quiet, safe and has bathrooms and showers. the rangers and volunteers are beyond friendly. The other campers are also very kind. The wildlife and nature were so great to witness. If you've never been camping like me, this is a great first  step!

chesterton-in-indiana-dunes-state-park.editorialSummary: Dune-lined park for hiking, swimming, fishing, cross-country skiing, birding & more, plus campsites.

reviewSummary.text: A beautiful hidden gem in Indiana. This was our first time here, and I'm glad we made the trip. Who knew you could drive 4 hours, and be at a beach in Indiana! The trails, and campground were very nice. The trails were great, and peaceful. I wish they were marked a little better. BE WARNED the mosquitoes here are crazy on the trails so come extra prepared for that! I had many bites especially on my feet. I will definitely come better prepared for next time. The trails were beautiful, and well maintained. The beach was beautiful, and clean. The bathrooms at the beach were very dirty is my only complaint. Great for some nighttime photography as well! Overall we can't wait to come back and visit!

I LOVE PATOKA LAKE!! The lake is so beautiful!! The campground is very well maintained. The camp hosts are always so friendly and nice. The staff also.
If I got only one vacation week a year, I’d spend it here!! The wildlife is so pretty to watch.
Feeding the fish at the marina is my granddaughter’s favorite thing.

fort-wayne-in-johnny-appleseed-campgroun.editorialSummary: River access, campground, playground, basketball court & Johnny Appleseed's grave in a 31-acre park.

reviewSummary.text: Johnny Appleseed Campground is a hidden gem, perfectly situated in the heart of town with easy access to grocery stores, malls, restaurants, and all the amenities you might need. While it doesn't offer sewer hookups, the campground provides a convenient dump station and a pump truck service for just $10. The campground hosts, Marcia and Brenda, are incredibly friendly and always willing to lend a helping hand. Although the campground isn't massive, its shaded grounds and comfortable layout make it a great spot to relax and unwind. Highly recommend!

north-liberty-in-potato-creek-state-park.editorialSummary: Multi-use trails, lake boating & fishing, public archaeological sites & more, plus campgrounds.

reviewSummary.text:
Great campground. Sites a spaced well, plenty of room. Quiet. Very nice paved bike trail. Beautiful lake. Best water fill and separate dumping stations I've ever seen.
They are currently building a new inn on the lake.
We will definitely be back.

My family and I absolutely love this park, it’s been a favorite of our for a long time. We just recently had our first group gathering last week and had a wonderful time. We enjoyed a beautiful meditation and nature walk in the Wetlands side of the park. I highly recommend.

Very nice people took it over recently and are turning it around. It’s already very well maintained and the problems that apparently used to plague it are cleaned out. Very easy access, sites are well spaced, level, and clean. Water and electric at (nearly?) all. I had 30amps and assume all are at least that. Biggest of rigs would have no problem getting in. Some pull through, most back in, but very large. Very nice fields, trails, and playground for kids. Great location right on the river. Bathroom and shower house is very clean and nice. Dump station included and has full rinse hose. The city still manages the website and fails completely. Prices are $23-$25 night. Do call before going, or at least before parking, because they do take phone reservations but don’t publish that online or indicate reserved sites. Highly recommend for a quick overnight, or longer. Cute town a short walk away with a great ice cream shop and much more
Nice small state park. Scenic campground right on the river. Modern bathhouse with hot showers. Has a newer playground boat ramp and awesome bike trails.

Nice clean campground with big sites and a playground. Plenty of hiking trails and raccon river bike trail less than a mile away. Would have gotten 5 stars if they had a dump station for black and grey water.

We camped in a 5th wheel. The campground was clean. The folks in the office super helpful and friendly. The two bath houses were sufficient for anything you needed however, I did not use them. One in our group did and felt like everything was adequate. A beautiful river flowing through. Tons of walking and biking paths. And lots to do in town. My only complaint is the noise off Highway 52, but not much they can do about that!

I only gave 3 stars 🌟 because there was sooooo much dog poop 💩 on my site!!! I have a dog and am irresponsible pet parent and pick up after my dog. The amount of poop that was there meant that nobody attended and cleaned up my sight before I arrived. Otherwise our stay was wonderful quiet and peaceful.
Great place to camp. About 15 minutes outside of Pella and easy to get to. Sites are very spacious. Great walking/biking path. Fishing looks good but we didn't have the opportunity to actually do it.
Beautiful lake. Nice facilities. Large old trees providing shade ❤️
Great place to camp. About 15 minutes outside of Pella and easy to get to. Sites are very spacious. Great walking/biking path. Fishing looks good but we didn't have the opportunity to actually do it.

This campground is well maintained with very nice hosts.  Firewood is available on-site at a self serve station.  The bathrooms are clean and conveniently located.  Wallashuck is located in close proximity to the town of Pella which offers a lot of small town charm!

waterloo-ia-george-wyth-state-park.editorialSummary: Multiple lakes for boating, fishing & windsurfing plus multi-use woodland trails, campsites & more.

reviewSummary.text:
I am a ham operator and did an activation at this park. Loved the lakes and the bathrooms were clean.

A super cute state park and they also offer camping and have a boat dock for the boats for fishing.

We made it here on a Monday and set up. Not sure but only 3 rv sites appear available.  Donations are at the restroom buildings. Five days is the limit but we are overnighter. Appreeciate the lovely shade and amenities.

Here is a polished and clean version of your review:
Peaceful and Very Clean for an Overnight Stay
We stayed here for just one night while driving through, and I found the campground to be excellent. Based on our experience in October, it was very clean and wonderfully peaceful. The overall vibe felt both safe and relaxing, whether you're traveling alone or with a family.
The campground is set in a beautiful location, surrounded by equestrian farms. I really appreciated the wide spaces between each site and the many mature trees that provide shade and privacy. Many of the sites also feature a concrete pad, which is a nice bonus. We only needed an electric hookup for our short stay, and everything was working perfectly. If you choose a grass site the cost is $30 per night vs $40 for the concrete pad site.
As a fairly picky and clean traveler, I found the facilities to be in great condition. Yes, the bathroom and shower building may be a little dated, but they were exceptionally clean, which is what matters most.
For families, the amenities look good; they have a nice playground, tennis court, volleyball court, and basketball court.
I would absolutely choose to stay here again in the future.

One of the nicest Federal campgrounds we have stayed at so far.   The campsites have a good amount of space between them and overall it was quiet at night. The bathrooms were cleaned daily even during the shutdown. The sites are open to the sky with almost no branches overhead.  It's a nice spot for star gazing. We were here in October and we started to hear the fishing boats leaving the harbor around 5am. We enjoyed using the free shuttle to explore the hiking trails on the peninsula. The bike trails were challenging with loose pea stone gravel but scenic and fun.

bourne-ma-bourne-scenic-park.editorialSummary: Bucolic park by the Cape Cod Canal with camping, fishing, hiking & other activities.

reviewSummary.text:
If your a resident you can visit the park and enjoy the amenities.
My kids love the jumping pillow.
The pools are well kept and warm.
There is only a few tent sites but reasonably priced.
We really didnt need a golf cart as the park isn't huge, but
In did come in handy exp a night getting the little ones to the bathroom in a jiffy.

sagamore-ma-scusset-beach-state-reservat.editorialSummary: A 1.5 mile stretch along the Cape Cod Canal with camping, fishing pier, swimming areas & bike paths.

reviewSummary.text: A nice place for a morning walk. Especially after season.  A beautiful estuary environment exists  a short distance  south.  Not a swimming beach, cold water, rocky shore and very crowded in season, but bliss when everyone goes home!

salem-ma-winter-island-park.editorialSummary: Marine recreational park with seasonal RV & tent camping, a boat launch, lighthouse & historic fort.

reviewSummary.text: In my opinion, this is the best way to stay in Salem. A tent site is 38 a night. If you book far enough in advance you can stay close enough to the beach you will hear the waves while you sleep. As afar as the physical grounds, its okay, nothing special, its the location that makes it next level. The island is little and easy to.get around. If you have bikes, this is a perfect adventure for anyone wanting to be close enough to all the Salem action in October without the price tag. We walked everywhere. Its totally reasonbly walkable if you are a person who enjoys walking. There are ubers as well and for the most part ubers are cheaper than the parking in the center of town. You could always uber into the center and walk around there and uber back. It was $12 one way when I did it. Parking was 50. There is some sort of power station that does make some noise and planes regularly go overhead. As you walk around the little island you will hear these. It did not bother my ability to sleep. I will add video and photos to this review later today.

My stay was short but very pleasant! The campground seems to be a popular spot for fishers. It's well shaded, with clean bathrooms, a dump station, and firewood and ice for sale. The hosts even have a little cafe that's open in the morning where they do coffee and breakfast. There's a trail right by the entrance that makes it super easy to hop on for running, biking, or walking. It's 3 miles (or so) from the cute town of Frankfort which has lovely shops and a nice clean beach. Have already recommended this place to my parents 😀.

grand-haven-mi-grand-haven-state-park.editorialSummary: Sandy beach area on 48 acres with swimming, sunbathing, scenic views, a fishing pier & a lighthouse.

reviewSummary.text: Love this state park, so cool being able to camp right on the beach and the water! The spots are very tight though so keep that in mind, it took me a couple tries to get in the spot and I usually never have a problem with backing up my camper. I could barely fit my camper and truck in my spot, but once you get over how tight it is, it is a beautiful place. I will say be careful getting a site next to the bathrooms by the river, they do not turn off the outside lights and they are super bright at night, no problem for us in a camper we could just close the blinds but a tent would be rough.

petoskey-mi-petoskey-state-park.editorialSummary: State park offers camping, a mile-long bayside beach plus diverse woodland hiking trails.

reviewSummary.text: This place is gorgeous! A must see for anyone, in or out of State.  A truly 1 of a kind place, & if you know, you know. If not, you'll have to FAFO so to say. 🤣 Northern Michigan has many treasures, but Petoskey has the Petoskey Stone. You have to visit to get 1, because you can only get them here.

This little park was a great stay. We contacted the host in the morning to see if we could stay the night. I asked them if they could save us a site and we would be coming in late. She had no problem with coming in at 11pm. She was waiting for us and helped us into one of there 15 sites. We plan on staying again and maybe a little longer than 8 hrs. There's a few trails to walk and a nice playground for the kids.

rogers-city-mi-hoeft-state-park.editorialSummary: Forested park includes hiking, biking & skiing terrain, plus 1 mile of shoreline along Lake Huron.

reviewSummary.text: This is a really beautiful and well cared for park.  Vault Toilets for Day Use visitors are very clean and well kept.  The trails are beautiful for birding, and hiking and one takes you to a stream if you are in to rock hounding.  The beach access offers many ways to get access.  There is a wooden path that is easiest but there are also many dunes paths for those that want more of a fun challenge.  A few mosquitoes and a few flies for this time of year is expected, but not awful.

south-haven-mi-van-buren-state-park.editorialSummary: Park with lakeside sand dunes & woodland trails features picnic area with grills & modern campsites.

reviewSummary.text: Beautiful little area off the lake with plenty of short hike trails leading to the beach. It was raining off and on during my visit but a beautiful view anyway! Definitely hope to go back and spend some more time hiking and hanging out on the beach. (There are some beautiful rocks for anyone who collects. The sand embeds some glass looking pieces that makes some of the sedimentary rocks looks metallic. Stunning what nature can do!) Only took a star off because it was hard to navigate and find the trail heads. Could use some more signs.

traverse-city-mi-traverse-city-state-par.editorialSummary: Bustling urban park open for camping year-round offers heated restrooms, biking trails & a beach.

reviewSummary.text: We have stayed at the State Park Campground about 6x’s. We love it there. It is a long drive or we would go more often. A large state park campground with different size lots. There is a bridge that goes to the public beach area. A bike trail behind campground that provides access to stores and restaurants. It’s clean and well kept.

My sister booked a tenting site here a few days ago. We really loved it. Had the most amazing sunset ever over the lake. We were watching it while playing cards and eating dinner. Clean showers, bathrooms and check in was easy. Thanks for having us!

albert-lea-mn-myre-big-island-state-park.editorialSummary: Sprawling oak savanna & prairie area with a glacial esker offers wetland birding, camping & hiking.

reviewSummary.text: Gorgeous park, especially when the fall colors hit. Great hiking trails with lots of space. We stayed at the Big Island campground which was very cool. Unfortunately there were quite a few very noisy guests including some extremely yappy dogs and it made our stay significantly less relaxing, otherwise it would have been five stars.

bemidji-mn-lake-bemidji-state-park.editorialSummary: This park with diverse wildlife offers camping, hiking, fishing, picnicking & cross-country skiing.

reviewSummary.text: Had a fun 4 days despite the June 21 2025 storm. The staff was great helping out folks after the storm had passed. While some things were unavailable there was still plenty to do and we enjoyed our campsite. It is definitely a place worth visiting and the camping area is very nice. The shower and restroom area is centered in the campground.  Well lit at night so easy to find. There are also vault toilets available and are closer for some sites.  Lots of water points so filling up is very easy from your site in most cases. Will definitely return and highly recommend a visit when in the area or as a vacation destination.

brainerd-mn-crow-wing-state-park.editorialSummary: Riverfront preserve including campgrounds, canoeing, forested trails & a historic village site.

reviewSummary.text: Nice state park. Lots of hiking trails from campground. You can fish the Mississippi River from campsites. Bike trail was great, 7.5 miles to Baxter trail all paved and follows along river in the trees. Not much for kids to do with no playground observed. Electric sites are to close together with no privacy but non electric were separated by trees/shrubs. Bathrooms are older but were clean.

carolton-mn-jay-cooke-state-park.editorialSummary: Park with a suspension bridge & a historic cemetery offering camping, hiking & cross-country skiing.

reviewSummary.text: The perfect location for a state park that isn’t on the North shore. Nestles right before you head into Duluth, with the Saint Louis ripping right through it. I’ve been here many times on my way to/ from Duluth but this visit was special. On a weekday, low visitors and peak fall colors. It was stunning. Plenty of places to pull over and park to view the views

centerville-mn-rice-creek-chain-of-lakes.editorialSummary: 5,500-acre park with a boat dock, campsites, hiking & biking trails, a fishing pier & playgrounds.

reviewSummary.text: This is a great campground and so close to the Twin Cities. We have stayed in two different non-electric tent sites. Both were nice and had some privacy. I appreciate that they allow one night reservations, including on the weekend, instead of requiring two nights like every other campground.  We stay here on our way up North. My only suggestion is about safety in the shower room. Locking doors on the shower stalls in place of the frosted white, slightly see thru shower curtains would feel safer. Everything else is great!

Lovely quiet campground, clean and well maintained. I almost gave 5 stars, the only issue is that it's not super big-rig friendly (it's not impossible,  just some of the sites have trees too close to the campsites, you'll see a lot of them have bumper-height scars, especially at the edge by the road, we didn't hit ours but it took us about 5 tries to back in playing dodg'em with the trees and had to go in crooked so our slideout wouldnt hit a shrubby tree). If you have a smaller camper you probably wouldn't have a problem, and there are several sites we noted would be easier for future visits (I hesitate to write them here since it could make them harder to get... 7, 11, 17, 25, and then 22 is the only pull-through).  Also, if you come in from East Gull Lake Drive, there is a point right before you get to the recreation area where you think "this can't be right, I must have messed up!" (because the road gets narrow and looks like it's just going to some private cottages and there will be nowhere to turn around) and then there's a narrow one-lane bridge.  I really recommend coming in on Gull Lake Dam Rd if it works for your route at all.
Another review mentioned how diligent the rangers are about quiet hours, the reviewer was writing it as a criticism but I read that and thought "that sounds perfect!".  We did find it to be totally quiet after 10pm, if anyone who has anything to do with running this campground ever reads this, please keep up the good work!!  We also observed that the volunteer hosts were extremely on top of cleaning up sites after people left.
For activities, there is a playground, fishing near the dam (with a fish cleaning station), a place to put in canoes/kayaks and the park rangers hosted a few activities like nature bingo and a hike.  We were in the area for a family reunion, so we didn't participate in them but it was nice they had them and also that they told us about them when they checked us in.  There is also a day-use area of the park, which we didn't visit, but according to the pamphlet it has a boat ramp, swimming beach, another playground, picnic area, volleyball, basketball and horseshoes.
In the campground is a clean shower house with flush toilets and then vault toilets in 2 smaller buildings that were not stinky.  There are several water bottle fillers, which I've never seen in a campground before and we did take advantage of them.
We would definitely stay here again if we were in the area!

I've been to most of the churches in the area. Sandstone, Hinckley, Beroun and Rush City. The tree of my grandchildren go to church in Hinckley. So for now it's where I'm going. New priest only been there one Sunday. I also know many of the people that live in the Hinckley area.
Tennis courts near here are always fun to play at. They do have a lot of weeds and are not very well kept however!

luverne-mn-blue-mounds-state-park.editorialSummary: A 100-foot Sioux quartzite cliff & bison herd draw hikers, climbers & campers to this sizable park.

reviewSummary.text:
Blue Mounds state park is a great park in the middle of a seemingly unremarkable part of the state. One of the hikes across the prairie is hot and unshaded, so bring lots of water and dress lightly in the Summer months!
The bur oak trail on the South side of the park is beautiful and there are even some giant boulders to climb on, too!
There's relatively few trails/things to explore at this park, so savor the things you do here.
We had gorgeous fall days for camping! The campground is beautifully maintained and the bathrooms are wonderful.

soudan-mn-lake-vermilion-sudan-undergrou.editorialSummary: Home to the state's oldest iron ore mine, this park offers tours, trails & picnic areas.

reviewSummary.text: I just did the surface tour with Maddie and it was excellent!!  I thought I’d be disappointed since the underground tour was cancelled but having a guide for the surface tour made up for it. She was had so much knowledge of the mining industry and process. It’s hard to believe they don’t offer an above ground tour normally I feel like it would be hard to truly understand the rest of the process just walking around the other buildings.

photos.attribution: Lake Vermilion-Soudan Underground Mine State Park

reviewSummary.text: It's camping no need for any other explanation. First trip of year.

two-harbors-mn-split-rock-lighthouse-sta.editorialSummary: Known for its historic lighthouse, this park boasts trails, lakefront campsites & a rocky beach.

reviewSummary.text: This was a bucket list stop for me and the main motivation for our trip to the area, it did not disappoint! We purchased tickets ahead of time for the Keeper’s tour because I thought I read that it was a max of 10 per tour and I wanted to make sure we got in, however it seemed that if there was a bigger group they split the tours between guides for a max of 10 per group. Paid entry into the park is not required if you’re there for the tour. We arrived at 8:30 for the 9:00 tour - the building does not open until 10:00, so don’t expect to walk up and go in. However, our tour guide came out to greet us when she noticed people arriving and unlocked the door for us to use the bathroom before the tour, so that was appreciated. Amy was our tour guide and she was a delight to spend time with, obviously very knowledgeable and passionate about what she does and encouraged everyone to take their time for photos and gawking. The area is currently under construction so you will see some fencing and obvious construction work right now but I was still able to get great photos. Unfortunately it was smoggy from the wildfires so I didn’t get great shots from the iconic lighthouse viewing areas, but nothing anyone can do about that. I recommend wearing walking shoes as the paths are rocky and there are some stairs throughout the tour, obviously to go up to the lighthouse. The path to the iconic viewing spots out on the trails (separate from the tour but still required paid entry) is all dirt and gravel and there are SEVERAL stairs (long stair case) - we went down the stairs and took the dirt path back around to avoid going back up. The gift shop was the type I was comfortable spending money at, it is set up well and not full of junk. I also recommend walking through the building and watching the video about the lighthouse. Pay for the tour, you won’t be disappointed!

We’ve camped at Sakatah Lake State Park several times over the years, and it continues to be a great place to camp in southern Minnesota. The campsites are well-maintained and nicely spaced, the restrooms are clean, and the park itself is awesome.

Wildlife viewing is always a highlight—but like many other places, mosquitoes can be a factor. Be mindful of the season and recent weather. In a wetter year, the mosquitoes can be intense! So far in 2025, they haven’t been nearly as bad compared to previous visits. Still, packing bug spray is always a smart move.

Overall, it’s a great place to relax, hike, bike the Sakatah Trail, and enjoy nature. Highly recommended!

The campground was really nice. We were there on the weekend that they had the Halloween decorating contest. We ran to the store and bought a bunch of stuff to decorate, only for them not to do the contest. We asked about it and they said they would post the winner on their page the next day. They did not post it so I called and the gentleman said he would find out and get back to me well that has been 2 weeks. Such a bummer.

Great fishing in this lake. No problems catching plenty of bass! The locals are friendly and willing to share fishing knowledge (to an extent) The camp ground is nice and the lake manager is availible on a regular basis. Nice walking or biking trail. Nature trail beside the campgroud is accessible but grown over slightly.

lawson-mo-watkins-mill-state-park.editorialSummary: Campground & 100-acre lake featuring a textile mill & living-history farm, plus a biking path.

reviewSummary.text: We love this place!!! Awesome spot in a perfect location - close to a nice town with lots of great stuff, including a Natural Grocers! The campsite hosts are very nice and super accommodating!!! We are very happy with our overall experience and can’t wait to come back!!!

park-hills-mo-st.editorialSummary: This park permits vehicles such as motorcycles & snow mobiles, plus offers lake swimming & trails.

reviewSummary.text:
This was a much larger Park than I expected. I also had no idea that it was a very popular place for off-road vehicles. We selected the campground closer to the off-road vehicle area which includes 54 mi of off-road trails.

The campground was large and spacious. I had one of the cleanest bathrooms I think I've seen in a Missouri State Park. Even the 2 vault toilets next to our campsite were kept clean.

While you could hear sometimes the dirt bikes or four-wheelers off in the distance from the campground and people would drive around the campground on them. They were respectful of the area and didn't go speeding through. And everybody was respectful of quiet hours, not revving up their engines all night.

The campground locked at night and you needed a code to get in and out at night. Probably to deter thieves

I did not get to check out the Horace centric campground because it was gated shuts and I think you needed a code to get in and out.

Best camping along the Katy Trail hands down.  Whether you are hiking, biking, horse riding, or RVing, this is the place for you.  Wide open space,  lots of shady spots,  great location,  showers,  laundry, and quiet! So many places along the Katy are very loud.  Here you can hear yourself think and hear the birds sing.  Great place especially heading westbound cross county.  Also very dog friendly and very very good value.  Thanks Kelly for going above and beyond in helping me with my bike issue!

Beautiful area, very nice camping spots. It was very peaceful, except for the mowers. We camped during the week, and the mowing must be done, so I really can't complain. Restrooms were clean and well-maintained. We'd definitely camp here again!

weston-mo-weston-bend-state-park.editorialSummary: This park with a campground offers paved & unpaved trails & overlook views of the Missouri River.

reviewSummary.text: This is a really nice park. We stayed 4 nights in the campground. The camp hosts were the best we've ever encountered. They were very helpful to us "rookie" travel trailer people. They took great delight in helping anyone needing assistance. I learned a lot from them. The trails are great and well maintained. The 2.75 mile paved trail is a bit rough and very hilly. It is well worth going on. I highly recommend this park!

It was quiet and pretty campground fairly well  maintained.  The vault bathroom did not have hand sanitizer or any other way to clean your hands. Or picnic table was also in bad shape with termites that had been there for a while. Lots of shade trees. Fire pits were nice. They gave you a map on entrance. I felt as if the price was a little high. 14$ park pass and 25$ electric camp site.

norfolk-ne-ta-ha-zouka-park.editorialSummary: Park offering facilities for softball, sand volleyball, horseshoes & disc golf, plus a playground.

reviewSummary.text: They have done a lot of work here over the last few years and this park is absolutely gorgeous! Including a nice playground and free splash park, as well as river front trail and seating areas and great shelters for picnics.

Clean quiet park with spacious electric only spots.  Fill up freshwater before you park, dump as you leave.  Only $20 a night!  Didn’t give it five stars because we like having full hook ups and pull thru spots, but it is a great campground for the price!

We had a great time at Gotta Get Away Campground. We stayed towards the later side of August (1 night) on our camping trip out  to South Dakota. It was quiet, only seasonal campers were there at the time. Staff was great, it was kid and dog friendly. The pool is huge and it was super warm. There is an awesome Arcade and nice clean laundry facilities and restrooms w/ shower. On our way back through we stayed on labor day weekend. The place was packed! I think we might have gotten the last site available. There were kids, pets, golf carts. It was really lively and there were tons of activities to do with my kids. They also had food trucks while we were there, there was a pizza truck and donut truck during our stay- both were great and it was a nice treat. We had a great time at this campground- it was clean, well managed, easily accessible to the highway and fairly priced! We will definitely be back again!

Absolutely immaculate and gorgeous state park on Lake Eerie.
Spacious campsites, extremely spacious, and beautiful views, every campsite we walked by was private and comfortable.
People are friendly.
Campsites are very clean
Trails are gorgeous.
Water and bathe is close by and the bathroom is very clean.
Beautiful birds throughout the campground, extremely enjoyable.
We feel extremely blessed that we got to stay here for a night.

springfield-oh-buck-creek-state-park.editorialSummary: Rolling hills with hiking & bridle trails, a lake for fishing & boating, plus campsites & cottages.

reviewSummary.text:
We stayed at the group campground. It has a bathroom for men and women. It does not have showers or an electrical receptacle inside the building. It has several fire rings and picnic tables, a paved parking lot with multiple places to park. The marina is down the road. Signs for the park are not well established. However, each entrance is down in back. The campground side of the park has multiple side road loops and offshoots down to the water, archery, marina, beach or disc golf areas.
The Buck Creek trail is closed 2 miles from the head of the trail. The is a bridge is out. Also, at the bottom of the dam it is quite smelly from the effluent being released.
We would definitely do another stay. It was an enjoyable place with lots of activities over the first weekend of October for Halloween.
Good place to camp. For a fair ground. Attended a bluegrass festival. Had a ball.

cascade-locks-or-viento-state-park.editorialSummary: Picturesque park draws visitors with its access to windsurfing, scenic hikes, & a modern campsite.

reviewSummary.text: This park is in the worst location possible. It’s sandwiched between an interstate and a very active railroad. Not only a railroad but also a railroad crossing so you hear the very loud train blow the horn 3-4 times when it passes by. How many times does it pass by you ask? Multiple times an hour and that’s 24/7. My rv was backed up to the interstate so between the heavy traffic, tractor trailers, motorcycles, etc. and the train, I didn’t sleep the 3 nights I was there. I sleep with a box fan next to my head but it was no match for this noise level. I felt bad for the people in tents. Also, there’s no tent area so tons of tents next to rv’s which is annoying due to noise. But hey, the train and traffic will pretty much drown out people noise anyway at this campground. The website states certain sites will hear the trains more. Rest assured EVERY site hears it loud and clear. The north loop is just a small circle and there are no quiet sites. Sure, there’s a lake and people seem to go for kite surfing. Get a day pass and do that if that’s your thing. I’d never recommend anyone to actually camp here.

nehalem-or-nehalem-bay-state-park.editorialSummary: 890-acre oceanfront park with hiking, biking & equestrian trails, campsites, yurts & an airstrip.

reviewSummary.text: I'm camping with a popup trailer at the comfortable, and beautiful Nahalem State Park Campground. Spacious campsites with loads of green level space for tents or for hanging out. Dogs allowed on leash and off-leash at the beach. Thoughtfully set up with places to deposit dog bags and get additional ones as you're walking through. There's a brand new and especially nice bathroom building near my site (D43). Some sites are shaded (which also protects you from the wind on windy days). Both bathroom and shower buildings were clean and well kept. It feels really nice here, and while you have to climb over what amounts to a large sand dune to get to the beach - what a lovely beach it is. This park is far enough from 101 to be very quiet. Prices are much more reasonable than private RV parks. I enjoyed the new looking water and electric hookups (50A, 20A, 110V). There are warm lights that come on by the hookups at dark and add a bit of charm.

Nice park with a shaded trail system, marina, and small store. The trails offer a peaceful walk, though they were a bit messy—covered in leaves and branches. Some areas feel dated, with old equipment stations left behind and picnic tables that are worn but still usable. It’s an average park with decent lake access, but for a paid day-use area, I expected a little more upkeep and care.

We had an amazing stay at this campground! The sites were spacious, clean, and well-organized—everything felt thoughtfully maintained. The restrooms were spotless, which made a huge difference in comfort during our visit. What really stood out was the team of caretakers—friendly, attentive, and always ready to help with anything we needed. Their service made us feel truly welcomed. Overall, it was a fantastic experience and we’re already looking forward to coming back. Highly recommend!

Chris and Lunda, camp hosts, helped me out when I couldn't get internet and I met some fun people who shared info about where I was going. The morning sun rise over the mts. And through the fog was lovely. I enjoyed the flock of geese call out and flying low following the river. Enjoyable night. I'd go back.

dunbar-pa-ohiopyle-state-park.editorialSummary: Gateway to the Laurel Highlands offers 20,500 acres of hiking, whitewater boating & picnicking.

reviewSummary.text:
This was an amazing experience for my wife and I. Plenty of visitors and lots of chances for we Louisiana natives to vist locals, and visitors from all over. Weather was really nice, colors have started, the river was awsome.
The buckwheat festival was on going. We also ran across a young lady getting married in the middle of the river. She had on white mech wedding train that was as cute as it could be. Icecream, pizza, and sandwiches what more could you ask for. Visited a 84 yr young woman with a history from out of a Movie storyline.

We got one of the new sites along the water with a spectacular view. There isn’t a better site to see the sunset. This place is the quietest campground we’ve stayed at. Not many people out at all. The check in was easy as the host family saw us and checked us in. The bathrooms are clean and spacious. Sites are spacious and clean also. You don’t feel like you’re on top of the site next to you. Most people here are in bigger RVs and fifth wheels is we assume they stay inside.

The only negatives we had is there is never anyone at the camp office so firewood is nearly impossible to get so I recommend bringing your own. The sites on the water are along the waking path with a fence dividing them. It’s fine, but just know the public and fisherman walk here and talk all day and night until 9pm when it’s locked. It’s not too crowded,  but they’re here. Also, no one monitors the front gate so anyone can come in. While eating dinner 2 teens rode their motorcycles in her with loud music and did a loop then left. There isn’t anything for kids or recreation on the campground so be prepared if they’re used to a playground or something. None of these are deal breakers to me, it’s such a great place. Other than that, you can’t find a better place.

Awesome campground on the Cumberland River. Loved staying here.. even the inside sites (not waterfront) are amazing. Listening to the pecans fall when the wind blows.. and the HUGE barges passing by are my favorite things about being here.

lawrenceburg-tn-david-crockett-state-par.editorialSummary: Creekside park with walking trails, camping & cabins, plus boat rentals & a massive swimming pool.

reviewSummary.text: Very clean and family friendly state park. Could easily be a 5/5 if they would get the “Olympic sized” swimming pool operational. Please quit advertising it on your website until you get it up and running.

winchester-tn-tims-ford-state-park.editorialSummary: Lakeside park offering a marina with boat rentals, fishing, a golf course, cabins & camping.

reviewSummary.text: Absolutely beautiful! Stayed in one of the cabins, and I loved every second of it. The cabin was a clean and spacious living area. The cabin has a large private porch to the master bedroom and a very large extended porch for the guest room and the dining area, all with outstanding views.  The trails in this park are beautiful and generally easy to hike with scenic views of the waterway and forests. The visitors center is wonderful and full of information. They have critters found in the area that are being rehabilitated, such as a hawk , a great horned owl, snakes, and others around for viewing. The rangers are knowledge and outgoing, providing great experiences to kids. We were able to hold a snake, rock climb, and get a nice tour before we wandered off to hit the trails. I recommend bringing the family and enjoying time outdoors. ALSO, apprently, this is Sasquatch country lol, so be on the lookout out. HAVE FUN!!!

mineral-wells-tx-lake-mineral-wells-stat.editorialSummary: Scenic area featuring trails to town, camping areas & mineral-rich waters for swimming.

reviewSummary.text:
Late Post | Winter Season

Stayed in a campsite back in January in our camper van. Such a great Texas State Park! Well maintained and the bathrooms were clean. Did a couple of trails and even saw an armadillo!

Also, love that they have a little free library where you can take/leave a book! Next time we camp there, I’ll definitely bring some books to leave.

needville-tx-brazos-bend-state-park.editorialSummary: Home of an observatory, lakes & fishing, plus hiking/biking trails, camping & lots of alligators.

reviewSummary.text:
Absolutely beautiful park and a great escape from the city!
Brazos Bend State Park is one of the best parks I’ve visited in Texas. The trails are peaceful, clean, and surrounded by nature, you can see tons of birds, deer, and even a few alligators from a safe distance. The park is very well-maintained, and the staff are friendly and helpful.

Perfect for hiking, biking, or just relaxing by the water. I loved how easy it was to spot wildlife without feeling unsafe, and the camping areas are clean and quiet with plenty of space. If you go, bring a camera and some bug spray, and visit early in the morning or near sunset for the best experience.

Highly recommend for families, nature lovers, or anyone who just wants to disconnect and enjoy a bit of peace in the outdoors.

valley-view-tx-johnson-branch.editorialSummary: Section of lake state park with easy to challenging hiking & biking trail loops & picnic sites.

reviewSummary.text: We had such a great time at this state park. Very friendly and helpful rangers, clean and fun park. We stayed over the weekend in our RV (site 71) and had a great time. Most folks settled down after the sun dropped. Campers were helpful and friendly. This was our first time camping in our new RV and I think we are spoiled. Love this park! We can't wait to come back.

chehalis-wa-rainbow-falls-state-park.editorialSummary: 139-acre camping park on the Skagit River with a waterfall, a fuchsia garden, trails & swimming.

reviewSummary.text: It is a nice campground. Lots of trails to walk to. They do have water area for washing dishes for people that camp. Bathroom are nice and clean.

We were looking for a reasonable priced place for a quick trip in our toy hauler. We had some long overdue maintenance work we needed to get done so we were not looking for anything fancy. This place was perfect. It is easy to get to from downtown Cle Elum and has a lot of spots to choose from. We came midweek so reserving a spot was no problem a couple of days out. The spots themselves range from open grass to nestled in the trees. Our spot was grass but next time we will try to get something in the trees. When we went to the office, the gal at the desk was super friendly and helpful. She gave us insider tips on the best spots to stay next time we come back.

I am knocking off one star due to the constant freeway noise. The property butts up to I-90 so the noise never dies down. It's not really the campgrounds fault but it is something to be aware of if you are sensitive to noise while trying to sleep. I think the sites in the trees would be better but we were not there so I can't say for sure. Our site also took a bit of side to side leveling but that is part of camping.

If the freeway noise doesn't bother you, it is a great, affordable, and close to town campground. We will definitely come again.

This is a nice place bring the kids to swim and kayak, There is a nice roped-off swim area and a boat launch. There's plenty of grass and picnic tables. There's also ample parking. We usually visit several times during the summer. Be sure to bring your Discover Pass!

blue-mounds-wi-blue-mound-state-park.editorialSummary: A swimming pool, plus hiking, biking & cross-country skiing trails & a campground in a hilltop park.

reviewSummary.text:
This park offers a lot!

Hiking trails, playground, two towers with great views and an additional viewing area with a unique winding walkway, a very nice swimming pool, mountain biking trail, rocks, flowers, and wildlife. This place has it all!

There is a lot of parking here in several areas. Quite a few restrooms. Lots of tables and grills. Several shelters. This is a great place to spend a day or a weekend.

Can't go wrong visiting here, I highly recommend it!

Be sure to check out Cave of the Mounds when in the area, especially if you've never been. It's an incredibly unique experience, and one of my favorite places in the state!

cornell-wi-brunet-island-state-park.editorialSummary: 1,300-acre park on the Chippewa & Fisher rivers, offering camping, fishing, boating & hiking trails.

reviewSummary.text:
It smells so good here! Almost more Autumn than Spring going into Summer. It was wonderful!

I spent all of my time in the island (didn't have enough time for the Nordic Trail), but it was still well worth visiting.

Beautiful area, lots of campsites with water access, plenty of parking and restrooms. There's a small beach, a playground area, a ball field, and easy-going hiking trails.

Though we're still not in bloom, I recommend traversing the entire island to take in everything there is to offer. There are great water views all around, and plenty of wildlife running around. A few small flowers popping up here and there.

The flying insects were not bad at all, and I had no ticks from my time here.

Well worth visiting! Seems like an ideal place to camp and bring kayaks or a canoe.

fish-creek-wi-peninsula-state-park.editorialSummary: Huge scenic park with a 38-acre island, 18-hole golf course, bike trails, camping & more.

reviewSummary.text: 8/21/25 - this park is absolutely gorgeous! Definitely a MUST STOP and easily a reason to visit Door County all on its own. This was our favorite stop of the entire trip!!! Lots of bikers enjoying the shady roads and trails. The views are spectacular and Eagle Tower is such a unique structure, with a fantastic view and picture opportunities. Numerous picnic and camping areas to be enjoyed. Lots of water all around to enjoy as well. Very scenic and so much to do!

This is a quiet and well maintained little campground close to downtown.   Most sites have electric only but there are clean bathrooms and showers available.   It's a 7 minute drive to downtown Madison and the university.  The biking and hiking trail system is amazing as well.

trempealeau-wi-perrot-state-park.editorialSummary: Scenic park featuring hiking trails over bluffs with river views plus camping & picnic areas.

reviewSummary.text: I love this place some of the best and most scenic hiking trails in the wisconsin state park system that I found so far. Just be aware that these trails have a lot of elevation gain and drop and can be considered challenging to some people. But if you can brave the hike, the views are stunning. I would highly recommend.

two-rivers-wi-point-beach-state-forest-c.editorialSummary: 3,000-acre recreational park on Lake Michigan with forests, sandy beaches & a historic lighthouse.

reviewSummary.text: We camped for 4 nights over a long weekend.   The sites are nice with many having electric hookups.  Many of the sites have quite a bit of privacy.  They do have several buddy sites.  The bike trail was a beautiful peaceful ride.  Bummer, there are no tours of the lighthouse.  The beach is beautiful and a wonderful walk option.  It was great to be able to get ice cream and breakfast at the lodge on the weekend.

We have been going to Tunnel Trail every year for the last 6 years. We’ve stayed in the cabins and in our own tents. I love that the trail is right off the campground - super easy to get to. The people are very nice in the office too. We love the heated pool - a great way to cool off after a morning bike ride with the kiddos. Only thing we wish would change is the main bathrooms haven’t had working showers for three years. There are additional showers on the grounds but if it’s busy we end up waiting to take a shower. We just went this past weekend and the campground is looking great - trees are trimmed and people are working hard to make it nice despite the owner’s husband passing away unexpectedly this past year.  Campsites are spacious, the store is stocked with any supplies you might forget and you can get your bike pass right in the office before hitting the trails. We’ll be back every year!

exception-this-is-a-55-campground-in-tuc.editorialSummary: Sociable RV resort with a pool, ball courts, gym, library, craft rooms, dog park & putting green.

reviewSummary.text: This was our second visit. Really enjoyed our stay. Great location. Desert so mostly gravel. Good sized dog park but also a lot of places to walk a dog - just make sure your dog will go in gravel. Residents in the area all very nice. It is in the flight path of the airport and fighter jets practice overhead but I loved that. Did not use their facilities but they looked nice. Even had a dog bath station.

exception-there-s-no-trail-lincoln-city-.editorialSummary: Memorial honoring President Lincoln & his family offers boating, camping, swimming & hiking.

reviewSummary.text: We hiked the trails in early November and it was beautiful. The paths are well maintained and easy to follow. The fire tower offers beautiful panoramic views and is worth the climb. The lake happened to be drained when we went but it was still well worth the visit!

exception-there-s-no-trail-gatlinburg-tn.editorialSummary: Scenic, riverside RV/tent campsites & rustic cabins, plus a general store & recreational activities.

reviewSummary.text:
⸻

Site 16 (Premium Riverfront)

We just stayed here and wanted to share an honest review for fellow RVers.

Pros:
•	The campground itself is very well taken care of — clean, landscaped, and decorated really cute for fall, which gave it a welcoming feel.
•	Staff were friendly and helpful, always quick with a smile.
•	The surrounding area is great, lots to see and do nearby.

Cons (specific to our stay at Site 16):
•	We booked a premium riverfront site, but the spacing left a lot to be desired. Our spot was right on top of our neighbors — so much so that we couldn’t comfortably open our door or blinds without feeling like we were staring into their camp, and vice versa. Definitely no privacy.
•	We noticed dog feces in multiple areas of the campground that hadn’t been picked up, which was disappointing.
•	A few trailers down, campers were smoking, and because the sites are so close together the smell drifted right to us. Not pleasant at all.

Overall:
It’s a nicely maintained campground with friendly staff and a cute atmosphere, but if you’re looking for space and privacy, I’d be cautious about booking the premium riverfront sites — especially Site 16. Hopefully management can address the spacing and cleanliness issues, because with a few changes this could be an outstanding place to stay.

tucson-az-rincon-country-west-rv-resort.editorialSummary: Sociable RV resort with a pool, ball courts, gym, library, craft rooms, dog park & putting green.

reviewSummary.text: This was our second visit. Really enjoyed our stay. Great location. Desert so mostly gravel. Good sized dog park but also a lot of places to walk a dog - just make sure your dog will go in gravel. Residents in the area all very nice. It is in the flight path of the airport and fighter jets practice overhead but I loved that. Did not use their facilities but they looked nice. Even had a dog bath station.

lincoln-city-in-lincoln-state-park-in-li.editorialSummary: Memorial honoring President Lincoln & his family offers boating, camping, swimming & hiking.

reviewSummary.text: We hiked the trails in early November and it was beautiful. The paths are well maintained and easy to follow. The fire tower offers beautiful panoramic views and is worth the climb. The lake happened to be drained when we went but it was still well worth the visit!

gatlinburg-tn-greenbrier-campground.editorialSummary: Scenic, riverside RV/tent campsites & rustic cabins, plus a general store & recreational activities.

reviewSummary.text:
⸻

Site 16 (Premium Riverfront)

We just stayed here and wanted to share an honest review for fellow RVers.

Pros:
•	The campground itself is very well taken care of — clean, landscaped, and decorated really cute for fall, which gave it a welcoming feel.
•	Staff were friendly and helpful, always quick with a smile.
•	The surrounding area is great, lots to see and do nearby.

Cons (specific to our stay at Site 16):
•	We booked a premium riverfront site, but the spacing left a lot to be desired. Our spot was right on top of our neighbors — so much so that we couldn’t comfortably open our door or blinds without feeling like we were staring into their camp, and vice versa. Definitely no privacy.
•	We noticed dog feces in multiple areas of the campground that hadn’t been picked up, which was disappointing.
•	A few trailers down, campers were smoking, and because the sites are so close together the smell drifted right to us. Not pleasant at all.

Overall:
It’s a nicely maintained campground with friendly staff and a cute atmosphere, but if you’re looking for space and privacy, I’d be cautious about booking the premium riverfront sites — especially Site 16. Hopefully management can address the spacing and cleanliness issues, because with a few changes this could be an outstanding place to stay.

This was a good location for traveling through, wanting to see a few sights in St. Louis. It is a basic, gravel campground. You need to be self-contained. We were in site 10. The hookups were all behind our parking space, so would have required multiple hoses, etc. Doable, but since we were only there 1 night, we opted to only hook up electric (we needed the a/c!). Easy drive into St. Louis to check out The Arch. Easy walk to the Louis & Clark Confluence Tower. Office staff was friendly and helpful when we were making reservations. OK for overnight or two. Other campers were friendly and seemed to be there for a longer period - working. Some highway noise. GREAT Verizon signal and internet!!!

This was our first time camping at Fort Warden, and will not be the last! We were there for 4 nights, with our trailer.
The campsites are spacious, and open. The campground has access to .. everything! Trails galore, and strolls to the sandy beaches. The battery's - there are a few! - are interesting to explore. And offer some unique views from the top.

Great place to camp. Lots of hiking and places to explore. In the forest yet still close enough to walk to the beach. Make sure to take time to sit at the bluff near the end of Eisenhower Ave and watch the sunrise.
